Case study

Affiliate journey

I led front-end research, reconnected the client with their customers’ unmet needs, and delivered product concepts resulting in a 29% jump in engagement across 91,000 affiliated businesses.

Story

Our client – a major tech company – runs a network of 91,000 businesses. Business affiliates join to increase time-to-market, generate leads, and grow revenue. Managers act as their go-between to navigate this network. One day, they were gone. Replaced by an online self-service portal. Affiliates struggled to adapt. The client hired us to study existing actors, describe new products, and recommend a path forward.

Challenge

Increase Affiliate engagement with self-service tools while lowering the dependency on human support.

Key project contributions

  • Discover the current state (four weeks)

    I cut my team’s synthesis time in half using journey map co-creation.

  • Describe the future state (two weeks)

    I fought to share the customer’s perspective with a board game.

  • Define the path forward (two weeks)

    I guided new team members through the delivery of seven concepts.

Process

Discover the current state (four weeks)

I cut my team’s synthesis time in half using journey map co-creation.

Research challenge

My team's first research goal? Become fluent in our client's domain to earn their trust. We used a mix of desk research, interviews, and a hypothesis workshop. During the background period we asked, “how would you describe your Affiliate's end-to-end experience in the Affiliate Network?” The outputs were many: proto-personas, rough journey maps, and a stack of research questions for our team to pursue. We now asked, "how might we explore the client's current knowledge of customers using in-depth interviews?" We chose this approach because the client's previous body of research, survey feedback, answered the "how" but not so much the "why" behind customer behaviors we had questions about.

Solution

To bridge the gap, I proposed an update to our research plan. Like the journey maps our client created, we orchestrated a co-creation exercise for Affiliates to break up two-hour interviews. My team agreed that this methodology would allow us to test several of our working hypotheses.

Outcome

  1. ➊ How Affiliates negotiated their journey was less about persona type and more about context. Behaviors and values shifted based on circumstance. We coined these phenomena Mindsets.
  2. ➋ Affiliates took nonlinear paths in their journeys. Sometimes they got stuck on “dirt roads”, other times they cruised along “the highway.” But what were the mitigating forces, and what kinds of mindsets were a factor in this environment? The puzzle came together on our affinity board by grouping customer's pain-points.
  3. ➌ Affiliates were affected by conditions out of their control, but caused by our client unintentionally. Managers had higher priorities, so theirs took a back seat. Sales tools had bugs, causing leads to vanish. Weeks passed without a phone call returned. Uncertainty got in the way of aspirations. Affiliates were at the mercy of the client. As one Affiliate put it, "We are a krill swimming beside a huge whale. If they move just a little bit, they crush us."

Describe the future state (two weeks)

I fought to share the customer’s perspective with a board game.

Workshop challenge

Here's the messy the part (you gotta have a messy part, right?). We tried to shoehorn our interview synthesis board into a journey map-esque spreadsheet. Helpful for identifying milestones. Not helpful if the route Affiliates take to get to the milestones looks like a roller coaster. What we learned about Affiliates required pause for an alternative deliverable. Not a journey map, like the one engraved in the statement of work. No. Something like a board game that forced players to experience the frustrations voiced by Affiliates.

Our internal leadership balked at the pitch. But often the spirit of research is to welcome the occasional raised eyebrow. It means you're on to something. With constructive dialog we found a compromise together. By walking the client through our findings, they would need to arrive at a similar conclusion. The client’s exact words were, “this could be a game.” We had one week to prepare a finished product.

Solution

I’ve struggled in the past with behemoth synthesis sessions. I championed just-in-time synthesis. The rolling debriefs sped up the bid to sprinkle Affiliate quotes across the milestones on the game board. We held an open invite in the studio. Colleagues played the game and refined the mechanics with us. It was ready for the workshop.

Outcome

  1. ➊ Tactile play made it easier to consume an enormous volume of information in a brief span of time.
  2. ➋ Clients sought out copies of the game to "take home" and play with their respective departments. (We camouflaged the board game, matching the style with the client's brand guidelines in an effort to infiltrate hearts and minds.)
  3. ➌ Fjord was contacted later to host the game at a leadership retreat

Reflection

The client had warned us, "our organization is suspicious of outside research.” We chose to use desk research in combination with in-depth interviews to provide two data points that grounded the evidence in convergent validity. If their quantitative data was the "how," our qualitative data was the "why." Given more time, I would have liked to walk peripheral clients through our analyses.

After 11 years at this company, this (board game) was most informative and fun activity I’ve been through. — Client Participant

Define the path forward (2.5 weeks)

I guided new team members through the delivery of 7 concepts.

Final deliverable challenge

Packing six weeks of research into actionable recommendations sounds daunting. Thankfully, we followed a tight collaborative process with our client. Following the game activity, the workshop teams stepped through a series of exercises. They iterated mockups, then prioritized twelve winners. Over two weeks, my team worked with the client to bring those twelve ideas into the polished form you see here. My personal challenge was taking on a transitional leadership role. While two new colleagues came aboard, three more departed.

Trever was the glue holding the two phases of the project together. He was my personal go-to for input I needed to move forward. He owned the final deliverables, providing content, useful visual direction, and stellar copy.— Ki, Senior Visual Designer

Solution

Is a designer a copywriter? The concept storyboards needed to speak to business people, product owners, developers and other designers. With that audience in mind, I worked with our Design Director and Senior Visual Designer to stitch together a story for each concept. We turned sketches into polished storyboards that outlined the strategic impact of each concept.

Outcome

Our recommendations increased self-governance for Affiliates. Several concepts have since gone into v1 and v2 production. First quarter reports showed a 29% increase in customer engagement.

Next steps

One month later, we were back at it, presenting the board game to our client’s greater leadership team. Requests to “play the game” continued to roll in before I left Fjord.

Details

Team

I was the Design Research Lead, and interim Design Lead. Team included one design director, two interaction designers, one project manager, one visual designer, one solutions architect, and one account lead.

Responsibilities

Operations, desk research, expert, stakeholder, customer interviews (in-depth pair, group, and single person), synthesis, artifacts, mindsets, workshop design and facilitation, product storyboards, concepting, the final deliverable.

Research

1500 surveys reviewed, thirty-four interviews conducted, two workshops hosted, competitive analysis, literature reviews, landscape scans.
